answers.answer: Sure: likely either ophthalmic migraine (known also as "eye migraines") or a transient ischemic attack due to diesease of the heart, brain or cerebral blood vessels.You can use the search feature and the Health topics feature to review the many discussions of this.You need to see to types of physicians:  1. a Eye MD physician ophthalmologist for a baseline eye exam. when you schedule it ask also to schedule a visual field test.   2. You need to see your personal physician or an internist for a complete physical exam.You may need blood work, carotid doppler, ECHO cardiogram and MRI/MRA of the head.If you smoke, have high blood pressure, diabetes, or a family history of heart attacks or strokes it is even more important to have this done.You cannot diagnosis this as eye migraine until disease has been ruled out.VERY IMPORTANT.JCH III MD

question: First, I was examined by an eye doctor about 2 months ago.  55 years old, no glacoma or other medical problems with my eyes other than I need glasses to read.  I have had three esipsode over the last month.  Two instances of a blind spot occring in the center of by vision.  the spot is circular with jagged, colored edges.  The spot grows and the center becomes clear but the jagged egde of the spot continues to grow until it reaches the outer edges of my vision and completely disappears.  Whole episode lasts about 20 minutes.  today, I experienced double vision episode as I scanned across the computer.  blinked shook my head looked across the room.  Vision remained blurry for about 15 sconds and then went away.  No headaches, no other medical issues except slightly high blood pressure which is under control by meds.  Ideas?
title: Blind spot and double vision
